body:
This is intended behavior, I believe. The default method for a form is GET, and using `use:enhance` on a GET form doesn't make sense. SvelteKit automatically provides enhanced behavior for GET forms: https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/form-actions#get-vs-post

To fix this, you need to do one of:
- Specify `method="POST"` and provide a handler in `+page.server.ts`
- Remove `use:enhance` and handle the client-side navigation's query parameter in your `+page.ts` `load` function using `event.url`

See also: https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/form-actions#default-actions

There's a red warning:
> Actions always use POST requests, since GET requests should never have side-effects.

@tcc-sejohnson thanks for replying! That actually makes sense. Really I was only using use:enhance to do some preprocessing on the formData object prior to submission. 

Is there some other way of doing that? I did look in the on:submit handler, but did not see anything in that event object.

Maybe it's not a bad idea to check if the form would send a POST request, and stop the enhancement (dont preventDefault) if it doesn't.
I can't think of any use case for this, but there might be a `button` with [`formmethod="GET"`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/button#attr-formmethod).
Yeah, we should bail and print an error from `enhance` if `method !== 'post'`
@Rich-Harris is there some other way to get direct access to the formData object (ie, to remove empty entries and prevent annoying search=&nextItem= from showing up in your url?

@geoffrich you're my hero - I swear I tried that, or thought I did. 

That ... appears to work perfectly. Thank you SO much.
I do still think it would be useful for the same use:enhance to work with GET forms, but if that's by design, a maintainer can feel free to just close this. Clearly there's decent workarounds.

issue.title: [fix] throw error when using enhance on GET forms
issue.body:
closes #7896
closes #7972

### Please don't delete this checklist! Before submitting the PR, please make sure you do the following:
- [x] It's really useful if your PR references an issue where it is discussed ahead of time. In many cases, features are absent for a reason. For large changes, please create an RFC: https://github.com/sveltejs/rfcs
- [x] This message body should clearly illustrate what problems it solves.
- [ ] Ideally, include a test that fails without this PR but passes with it.

### Tests
- [x] Run the tests with `pnpm test` and lint the project with `pnpm lint` and `pnpm check`

### Changesets
- [x] If your PR makes a change that should be noted in one or more packages' changelogs, generate a changeset by running `pnpm changeset` and following the prompts. All changesets should be `patch` until SvelteKit 1.0

body:
Apologies for necroing this very old thread, but I also think it would be useful to support `use:enhance` for `GET` requests on forms. There are valid use cases for this that don't involve side effects.

For context, I'm using [Superforms](https://superforms.rocks/) to create a progressively enhanced HTML form that uses a schema validation library (like zod) for both client-side and server-side validation. To do this, I need to use that library's own `enhance` function:

```svelte
<script>
    const { form, enhance } = superForm(form, {
	validators: zod(schema),
	validationMethod: 'onblur',
    });
</script>

<form method="GET" use:enhance></form>
```

Unfortunately, because Svelte does not support `use:enhance` on `GET` forms, the library doesn't support it either. But I have a legitimate use case for this: My GET form needs to redirect the user to another route on submit (if JS is disabled) and serialize the data in the URL for easy link sharing. A POST request doesn't really make sense in my app and loses out on this native form-serializing behavior.

What's strange is that, as far as I could tell, this POST-only restriction doesn't actually change how Svelte or Superforms work. It seems to be more of a library preference rather than a safeguard against runtime errors. For example, if I edit the DOM by hand and force the form to be GET after my app mounts as an initial POST form, the app works fine and doesn't error.

Am I perhaps missing an obvious workaround to this?
